content.text: Calculate the weight of the balloon. Show your working
The resultant force on the balloon is \(54 \text{N}\)
Show that the acceleration of the balloon is \(0.45 \text{m/s}^2\)
The balloon accelerates upwards from rest at \(0.45 \text{m/s}^2\) for 8.0s
Calculate the velocity of the balloon after 8.0s
velocity =   .........
Calculate the distance travelled by the balloon in the first 8.0s
distance =   .........
Fig. 1.1 shows a balloon filled with helium gas
The mass of the balloon is \(120\mathrm{kg}\)
Define pressure
Describe how pressure in a liquid varies with its depth and with its density
variation with depth
variation with density
State two energy resources for which the Sun is not the main source
power generation in a nuclear power station
statement
explanation
power generation from waves in the sea
statement
explanation
State and explain whether each of the following methods of electrical power generation is renewable
State which state of matter, solid, liquid or gas, has the greatest thermal expansion and which has the least
greatest expansion
least expansion
Describe, in terms of the motion and arrangement of particles, the structures of solids and gases
solids
gases
Define specific heat capacity
A student carries out an experiment to determine the specific heat capacity of a metal. A cylinder of the metal is heated by a 12W electrical heater
State the readings that the student takes
Complete the ray diagram to draw the image formed by the lens. Label your image I.
Circle **three** descriptions in the list which describe the image formed in **(i)**
Fig. 4.1 is an incomplete ray diagram showing an object O, a converging lens and the principal axis. The focal points of the lens are each labelled F
State the name for the defect of vision that can be corrected by a converging lens
Describe how a converging lens corrects the defect in **(i)**
You may find it helpful to sketch a ray diagram
State the type of electromagnetic radiation, other than visible light, which is used in glass optical fibres
Give two reasons why these two types of electromagnetic radiation are used in glass optical fibres for high-speed broadband
Two types of electromagnetic radiation are used in glass optical fibres for high-speed broadband
The critical angle of the glass in an optical fibre is \(45^{\circ}\)
Calculate the refractive index of the glass
refractive index =   .........
Fig. 5.1 shows an optical fibre made of the glass described in (i)
On Fig. 5.1, draw carefully a ray of light in the fibre undergoing total internal reflection
Calculate the current in the resistance wire
current =   .........
The resistance wire of the heater has a length of \(1.2 \text{m}\) and a cross-sectional area of \(7.9 \times 10^{- 7} \text{m}^2\)
A new heater is designed using wire of the same material with length \(1.8 \text{m}\) and cross-sectional area \(5.8 \times 10^{- 7} \text{m}^2\)
Calculate the resistance of this wire
resistance =   .........
The 2500 W heater is used in a country where electricity costs 0.30 dollars per kilowatt-hour
Calculate the cost of using the heater continuously for two days
cost =   .........  dollars
An electric heater uses a resistance wire of resistance \(26\Omega\). The power dissipated in the resistance wire is \(2500 \text{W}\)
The current in the secondary coil is 2.5A
Calculate the current in the primary coil
current =   .........
Calculate the ratio of the number of turns on the primary coil to the number of turns on the secondary coil of the transformer
The voltage across the primary coil of a \(100\%\) efficient transformer is \(220\mathrm{V}\) and the voltage across the secondary coil is \(12\mathrm{V}\)
State what happens to this neutron
Explain how charge is conserved during this change
During \(\beta \text{- decay,}\) one of the neutrons in the nucleus changes
Complete the nuclide equation for the \(\alpha\) -decay of radon-212 to form an isotope of polonium, symbol Po
On Fig. 9.1, mark the positions of Saturn and Jupiter 5.0 years after the original positions shown
Label these positions \(\mathsf{S}_1\) and \(\mathsf{J}_1\). Show your working
On Fig. 9.1, mark the positions of Saturn and Jupiter 20 years after the original positions shown in Fig. 9.1
Label these positions \(\mathsf{S}_2\) and \(\mathsf{J}_2\)
State what is observed from the Earth's orbit after 20 years
Choose two words from the list to describe each planet
**gaseous** **large** **rocky** **small**
Jupiter
Earth
The average density of Jupiter is much less than that of the Earth
The gravitational field strength at the surface of Jupiter is greater than that at the surface of the Earth
Explain how these differences in density and in gravitational field strength are consistent with your answers to (c)(i)
density
gravitational field strength
The average density of Jupiter is \(1300 \mathrm{kg / m}^3\) and its volume is \(1.4 \times 10^{15} \mathrm{km}^3\)
Calculate the mass of Jupiter

Fig. 9.1 shows the Sun as the central dot and the planets Saturn, Jupiter and Earth labelled \(\mathsf{S}_0\), \(\mathsf{J}_0\) and \(\mathsf{E}_0\). The planets orbit the Sun anticlockwise. From the Earth's orbit, the planets appear aligned
(not to scale)
Assume that Saturn takes 30 years to orbit the Sun and that Jupiter takes 12 years to orbit the Sun
Show that 1 light-year = \(9.5 \times 10^{15} \text{m}\)
State one measurement that is taken when determining the speed \(v\) at which a galaxy is moving away from the Earth
Write down an equation relating \(v\) and the distance \(d\) of a far galaxy
State how the distance \(d\) of a far galaxy can be determined other than by using the equation in (ii)
